body_text.text: The outbreak of COVID-19 started in early December 2019 when a series of pneumonia cases of unknown causes were detected in Wuhan, China.4 On January 7th, the pathogen was identified as a novel coronavirus by Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and it was named 2019-nCoV by WHO on January 12, 2020 or SARS-CoV-2 by International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses. 2019-nCoV is made of a single-stand ribonucleic acid and its genome had been confirmed to be closely related with the coronavirus(SARS-CoV) which caused severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).5 Structural analysis showed 2019-nCoV had the ability to bind to the angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 receptors (ACE2) in human. The presence of ACE2 protein in the lower respiratory tract and on the enterocytes in the small intestine suggested the possible entry of the virus.6 It has been confirmed that 2019-nCoV uses ACE2 to enter the host cell.7

Pneumonia and cardiac disease often present in the same patient. The association between pneumonia and cardiac complications have been confirmed previously.8, 9, 10 New or worsening of heart failure, arrhythmia and myocardial are common cardiac complications. 8%-25.1% community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) patients developed at least one episode of cardiac complications during their hospital stay.9
,
11
,
12 Patients with underlying cardiovascular disease were more likely to develop CAP.13 In-hospital cardiac complications after pneumonia was associated with mortality9 and increased cardiovascular events on 2-year follow-up.14
body_text.section: Cardiovascular disease and cardiac complications in COVID-19 patients

body_text.text: Cardiac complications have also been reported in patients with coronavirus infections.15, 16, 17 In SARS patients, hypotension and tachycardia were common but usually self-limiting. Arrhythmia and cardiomegaly were rarely in patients diagnosed with SARS.15 Reversible subclinical diastolic dysfunction without systolic involvement was also observed in SARS patients.16 Acute myocarditis developed after the infection of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV), and myocardial edema was confirmed by Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). Severe left ventricular dysfunction was persistent on 3-month follow-up.17
body_text.section: Cardiovascular disease and cardiac complications in COVID-19 patients

body_text.text:
The effects of COVID-19 on the cardiovascular system are both similar and different with those of SARS and MERS. Among COVID-19 patients, cardiovascular disease is the most common comorbidities and cardiac complications are the most common complications.18
,
19
body_text.section: Cardiovascular disease and cardiac complications in COVID-19 patients

body_text.text:
The prevalence of hypertension and other cardiovascular disease was 15%- 32.6% and 2.5%- 15%, respectively.2
,
18, 19, 20, 21 Patients with underlying cardiovascular disease were more prone to develop cardiac injury,2
,
22 be severely ill18 or require intensive care.22
body_text.section: Cardiovascular disease and cardiac complications in COVID-19 patients

body_text.text:
Cardiac injury, which is indicated by elevated cardiac troponin I (cTnI) had also been confirmed in COVID-19 patients. The incidence of cardiac injury ranged from7.2 % to 27.8%2
,
18
,
19
,
22
,
23 and its incidence in ICU-patients and dead cases was 22.2% and 77%, respectively.18
,
24 Patients with elevated cTnI levels had a higher rate of cardiovascular disease,2 and cTnI was significantly increased in severe or deceased COVID-19 patients when compared to patients with milder symptoms.2
,
18
,
19
,
24
,
25 Higher cTnI level was also associated with higher complications2 and mortality.2
,
22 Elevated NT-proBNP level had be noticed2 and patients with elevated cTnI were more likely to have elevated levels of NT-proBNP.2 All these findings suggest the relationship between cardiac injury, cardiac dysfunction and poor outcome. And Monitoring cardiac troponin I longitudinally during hospitalization may help predict the progression of the disease.25
body_text.section: Cardiovascular disease and cardiac complications in COVID-19 patients

body_text.text:
Left ventricular dysfunction, persistent hypotension, acute myopericarditis, myocarditis, arrhythmia and heart failure have also been reported in COVID-19 patients.18
,
26, 27, 28, 29 Interstitial mononuclear inflammatory infiltration in heart tissue also provide evidence of myocarditis in COVID-19 patients.30 However, in a recent report of case-series from critical ill patients in the Seattle region, no cardiac dysfunction was detected by echocardiograms.29 Both echocardiography and cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) have been widely used in the evaluation of cardiac structural and functional changes, and we are waiting for the coming reports about their role in diagnosis and prognostication of patients with COVID-19.
body_text.section: Cardiovascular disease and cardiac complications in COVID-19 patients

body_text.text:
At present, the exact pathophysiological mechanisms of myocardial injury are not fully understood. Patients’ characteristics, the severity of infection and host reaction all participate in the development of cardiac complications.10 Direct damage by virus, systemic inflammatory responses and instability of coronary plaque and hypoxia have been proposed as possible mechanisms2 (See Figure 1
).

Direct pathogen invasion in severe pneumonia patients has been confirmed. In patients with severe pneumococcal, S. pneumonia was detected in the myocardium, leading to cardiac injury and local proinflammatory responses.30 And SARS-CoV was detected in 35% of patients with SARS, which suggested the possibility of direct damage to cardiomyocytes by the virus.31 At present, there were few reports about the pathological features of COVID-19. Since the SARS-CoV-2 is genetically closely related to SARS-CoV,32 SARS-CoV-2 may also share the same mechanism with SARS-CoV.

Pneumonia is a highly proinflammatory disease,28 and elevated levels of cytokines, which included C-reactive protein (CRP), interleukin-6(IL-6), interleukin-8 (IL-8), interleukin-10(IL-10), procalcitonin, interleukin-1beta(IL-1β), Tumor necrosis factor- alpha(TNF-α), Interleukin-10(IL-10), have been detected in COVID-19 patients, especially in ICU patients.19
,
33
,
34 Cytokines are important for infection control, but they can also lead to tissue damage and dysfunction (See Table 1
) . The level of cTnI was positively associated with plasma high-sensitivity CRP,2 which suggested the possible role of inflammatory storm in the development of cardiac injury. TNF-α had been detected in patients with heart failure35 and the positive correlation between TNF-α expression and the severity of heart failure, left ventricular dilation/hypertrophy and dysfunction was confirmed.36, 37, 38 Increased level of IL-1β was found in patients with acute myocarditis30 and elevated concentration of IL-6 was detected in patients with acute myocardial infarction and heart failure.30 The level of IL-6 predicted the adverse cardiovascular events following acute coronary syndrome and chronic heart failure.39
,
40 Serum IL-8 level elevated in patients with acute myocardial infarction41 and it is associated with mortality in patients with acute coronary syndrome.42 IL-10 was increased in patients with acute myocarditis43 and it predicted the poor outcome of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.44 So the virus triggers a series of immune responses and the production of cytokines storm may contribute to systemic presentation and multiple organ dysfunctions in COVID-19 patients.

The instability of coronary artherosclerotic plaques,45 the increased coagulation activation46 and platelet-aggregating activity,47 and hypoxemia due to abnormal ventilation/perfusion(V/Q) lead to decreased myocardial oxygen supply and myocardial ischemia. Activation of sympathetic nervous system lead to increased heart rate and peripheral resistance, which will further compromise coronary perfusion.48

Transient disturbance of endothelial function and vascular tone,49
,
50 volume overload due to impaired sodium and water metabolism51 and cardiac arrhythmia8 may contribute to the decreased left ventricular function or worsening of heart failure.

The role of ACE2 in the role of cardiac injury induced by COVID-19 has been proposed.22 SARS-CoV-2 share the same host receptor(ACE2) with SARS-CoV and its affinity to ACE2 is 10 to 20 fold higher than that of SARS-CoV.52 The use of ACEI/ARB will lead to increased expression of ACE2 and concerns about whether the use of ACEI/ARB will increase the risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection have been raised. However, in mice mode, SARS-CoV mediated myocardial injury through ACE2 with a remarkable decreased expression of ACE231 and blocking renin-angiotensin pathway can attenuate the severity of lung injury.53 This result suggests the possible protective effect of ACEI/ARB in COVID-19 patients. Abrupt discontinuation of ACEI/ARB and switching to other antihypertensive drugs may result in adverse cardiac outcome. At present, clinical trials are recruiting patients to evaluate the safety and efficacy ACEI/ARB in COVID-19 patients. Guo2 demonstrated there was no difference in mortality among patients with or without the use of ACEI/ARB. Before more data are available, it is not wise to discontinue ACEI/ARB in patients with COVID-19.54
body_text.section: The role of ACE2 in cardiac injure induced by COVID-19

body_text.text: At present, there is no effective vaccination or drug for COVID-19, only sympathetic therapy and empiric/supportive treatment are available. COVID-19 patients died due to their original comorbidities instead of pneumonia,55 which suggested the necessity of special attention to their original comorbidities while treating pneumonia.

Whether the medications patients used for cardiovascular disease will interfere with the treatment or the outcome of COVID-19 is still unknown. The possible effects of these drugs on pneumonia were from studies on patients with CAP / other virus pneumonia. As we mentioned above, at present there is no evidence of stopping ACEI/ARB in COVID-19 patients. And previous reports about the effects of ACEI/ARB on outcome of patients with CAP were conflicting.56, 57, 58 Statin can reduce systemic inflammation59 and improve outcome in CAP patients.58
,
59 However, beta-blocker was associated with increased 30-day mortality and the need for mechanical ventilation in patients with CAP.59 Calcium channel blockers, beta-blocker and thiazide were associated with a higher risk of 90-day hospitalization with pneumonia.60 No studies have demonstrated the effect of statins, beta-blocker, calcium channel blockers and diuretics on decreasing cardiac complications in patients with pneumonia.

Besides these, specific attention should be paid to medications with cardiovascular side effects for COVID-19, especially in patients with underlying cardiovascular disease. Common antibiotics, which are used for secondary bacterial infections, do exert effects on cardiovascular system. Macrolides (for example azithromycin)61 and fluoroquinolone61 have proarrhythmic effects, which include QT interval prolongation and polymorphic ventricular tachyarrhythmia. Vancomycin can induce the release of histamine, leading to peripheral vasodilation and severe hypotension.61 Some formulations of intravenous antibiotics contain substantial amount of sodium and attention should be paid to the daily sodium loads especially in patients with heart failure.48

Chloroquine/Hydroxychloroquine, which is an old drug for malaria, has been confirmed to be effective in patients with COVID-19.62
,
63 However, their cardiotoxicity which include arrhythmia, heart failure, myocardial disorder may be severe and irreversible.64

Anti-inflammatory therapies have also been implied in patients with COVID-19. Clinical trials about the effects of Tocilizumab (recombinant IL-6 monoclonal antibody) and Baricitinib (an oral-administrated selective inhibitor of the JAK1 and JAK2) on COVID-19 are recruiting patients. However, both drugs have been proven to be associated with elevated cholesterol levels.65
,
66 Although the association between altered lipid levels and cardiovascular risks is not identified, this side effect can't be dismissed. Anti-PD-1 antibody, as checkpoint inhibitors has also been applied in the treatment of COVID-19(NCT04268537, NCT04333914). However, its pulmonary, cardiac and neurological toxicity, which is usually fatal, should never be underestimated. Glucocorticoids, which can suppress inflammation, has been used as empiric treatment in severe COVID-19 patients.19 And several clinical trials are recruiting patients to evaluate its effectiveness and safety. However, corticosteroid use in patients with SARS,67 MERS68 and influenza69 did not improve patients’ outcome. And it is not recommended as the treatment for COVID-19 outside of clinical trials.70

The COVID-19 is rapidly spreading globally. At present, we still know little about this virus. Before vaccination is available, there is no effective therapy at present. As new clinical evidence emerges, the diagnosis and treatment may change. Clinical trials are necessary to determine the risk factors of cardiac complications, the mechanisms of cardiac injury and possible treatments to improve the outcome of patients with COVID-19.
None.
